questions.text: Investigation of choice to rule out biliary atresia in a 2-month-old child is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref.: Nelson textbook of pediatrics 19/e p1385

questions.text: A child comes with coarse facial features , big tongue with mucous discharge from nose at 10 months of age. The child was absolutely noramal at birth. On examination he was found to have enlarged liver and spleen diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref.: Nelson textbook of pediatrics 19/e chap77 Children with MPS I often have no signs or symptoms of the condition at birth, although some have a soft out-pouching around the belly-button (umbilical hernia) or lower abdomen (inguinal hernia). People with severe MPS I generally begin to show other signs and symptoms of the disorder within the first year of life, while those with the attenuated form have milder features that develop later in childhood. Individuals with MPS I may have a large head (macrocephaly), a buildup of fluid in the brain (hydrocephalus), heart valve abnormalities, distinctive-looking facial features that are described as "coarse," an enlarged liver and spleen (hepatosplenomegaly), and a large tongue (macroglossia). Vocal cords can also enlarge, resulting in a deep, hoarse voice. The airway may become narrow in some people with MPS I, causing frequent upper respiratory infections and short pauses in breathing during sleep (sleep apnea).

questions.text: An infant at 7 months of age presented with history of vomiting and failure to thrive. Patient improved with administration of intravenous glucose and came out of coma within 24 hours . After one month he returned with similar complaints . On evaluation which enzyme may be deficient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ref.: Nelson textbook of pediatrics 19/e chap74 Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency is an inherited disorder that causes ammonia to accumulate in the blood. Ammonia, which is formed when proteins are broken down in the body, is toxic if the levels become too high. The nervous system is especially sensitive to the effects of excess ammonia. Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency can become evident at any age. The most severe form occurs in the first few days of life. This neonatal-onset form of the disorder usually affects males; it is very rare in females. An infant with the neonatal-onset form of ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency may be lacking in energy (lethargic) or unwilling to eat, and have a poorly-controlled breathing rate or body temperature. Infants with this disorder may be described as "floppy" and can experience seizures or coma. Complications from ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency may include developmental delay and intellectual disability. Progressive liver damage may also occur. In some affected individuals, signs and symptoms of ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency may be less severe, and may not appear until later in life. The late-onset form of the disorder occurs in both males and females. People with late-onset ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency may experience episodes of altered mental status, such as delirium, erratic behavior, or a reduced level of consciousness. Headaches, vomiting, aversion to protein foods, and seizures can also occur in this form of the disorder.

questions.text: Initial fluid of choice for diarrhea in an infant is
questions.solution: A Ref.: Nelson textbook of pediatrics 19/e chap 48

questions.text: A 10 year old child presented with edema and decreased urine output. On evaluation serum albumin is 2.5g/ dl , S.creatinine is 0.5 mg/dL , urine protein is 3+ with no RBC or casts . The expected pathological change is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref.: Nelson textbook of pediatrics 19/e chap 519 Minimal change disease (MCD) is a major cause of idiopathic nephrotic syndrome (NS), characterized by intense proteinuria leading to edema and intravascular volume depletion. In adults, it accounts for approximately 15% of patients with idiopathic NS, reaching a much higher percentage at younger ages, up to 70%–90% in children >1 year of age. In the pediatric setting, a renal biopsy is usually not performed if presentation is typical and the patient responds to therapy with oral prednisone at conventional doses. Therefore, in this setting steroid-sensitive NS can be considered synonymous with MCD. The pathologic hallmark of disease is absence of visible alterations by light microscopy and effacement of foot processes by electron microscopy. Although the cause is unknown and it is likely that different subgroups of disease recognize a different pathogenesis, immunologic dysregulation and modifications of the podocyte are thought to synergize in altering the integrity of the glomerular basement membrane and therefore determining proteinuria. The mainstay of therapy is prednisone, but steroid-sensitive forms frequently relapse and this leads to a percentage of patients requiring second-line steroid-sparing immunosuppression. The outcome is variable, but forms of MCD that respond to steroids usually do not lead to chronic renal damage, whereas forms that are unresponsive to steroids may subsequently reveal themselves as FSGS. However, in a substantial number of patients the disease is recurrent and requires long-term immunosuppression, with significant morbidity because of side effects. Recent therapeutic advances, such as the use of anti-CD20 antibodies, have provided long-term remission off-therapy and suggest new hypotheses for disease pathogenesis

questions.text: A 1-month old child presented with conjugated bilirubinemia and intrahepatic . Cholestasis. On liver biopsy staining with PAS, red coloured granules were seen inside the hepatocytes . Probable diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ref.: Nelson textbook of pediatrics 19/e chap 338 Robbinsand Cotran's Pathological basis of disease 8/e p864 The periportal red hyaline globules seen here with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain are characteristic for alpha-1-antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency. More persons with AAT deficiency are likely to develop chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with panlobular emphysema.

questions.text: A 3.5 kg newborn born out of full – term normal vaginal delivery presented with respiratory distress not responding to surfactant therapy. There is a history of previous sibling’s death at one month of age due to respiratory distress What diagnosis should you suspect?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis Ref: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 20/e p 852- 2119 Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP) is a rare pulmonary disease characterised by alveolar accumulation of surfactant. It may result from mutations in surfactant proteins or granulocyte macrophage-colony stimulating factor (GM-CSF) receptor genes, it may be secondary to toxic inhalation or haematological disorders, or it may be auto-immune, with anti-GM-CSF antibodies blocking activation of alveolar macrophages. Auto-immune alveolar proteinosis is the most frequent form of PAP, representing 90% of cases. Although not specific, high-resolution computed tomography shows a characteristic “crazy paving” pattern. In most cases, bronchoalveolar lavage findings establish the diagnosis. Whole lung lavage is the most effective therapy, especially for auto-immune disease. Novel therapies targeting alveolar macrophages (recombinant GM-CSF therapy) or anti-GM-CSF antibodies (rituximab and plasmapheresis) are being investigated. Our knowledge of the pathophysiology of PAP has improved in the past 20 yrs, but therapy for PAP still needs improvement. Diagnosis of PAP is initiated by computed tomography (CT) scan and confirmed by staining of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF). Diagnosis of PAP rarely requires lung biopsy. Three main categories of PAP have been defined depending on the aetiology: auto-immune (previously named primary or idiopathic), secondary and genetic. Genetic PAP is seen especially in children, and radio-clinical presentation depends on the mutated gene. Adult forms are mostly auto-immune (with anti-granulocyte macrophage-colony stimulating factor (GM-CSF) antibodies) and/or secondary to toxic inhalation or haematological disorders, without anti-GM-CSF antibodies.

questions.text: Identify the following congenital defect:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Meningocele Ref: GhaiEssentia;l Pediatrics 8/e p 576 Meningocoele is a protrusion of meninges through a defect in the skull or spinal column (as in spina bifida) forming a cyst filled with cerebrospinal fluid

questions.text: A 2 year- old child with fever and barking cough for last 2 days presented to the pediatrics emergency at 2: 30am. On examination, respiratory rate is 36/min, temperature of 39°C and stridor heard only on crying. No other abnormality is found . What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) High – dose dexamethasone Ref: Ghai essential pediatrics 8/e p 376: Nelson textbook of pediatrics 20/e p 2032- 2034 Croup refers to an infection of the upper airway, which obstructs breathing and causes a characteristic barking cough. Treatment is as follows

choices.text: ORS with low-lactose diet and probiotics

questions.text: A 1 yr old infant presents with 10-12 episodes of watery stools per day for the last 9 days. Along with Zinc supplementation, what else should be prescribed to the child?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) ORS only Ref: Ghai essential pediatrics 8/e p294-295

questions.text: Milk is deficient in :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Iron and Vitamin C Ref: Ghai essential pediatrics 8/e p153

questions.text: All of these are a criteria for severe acute malnutrition in a 6 month- old child except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Height for age Ref: Ghai essential pediatrics 8/e p97 Severe acute malnutrition in 6 to 59 months includes Weight for height < - 3 SD Visible severe wasting Presence of bipedal edema; or Mid upper circumference below 11.5 cm Below 6 months, we exclude mid arm circumference from the criteria.

questions.text: How is undernutrition defined ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Weight for age< -2 SD Undernutrition is defined as weight for age <-2 SD.

questions.text: A 5 year sold child presented with continuous fever and features of sepsis with a BP of 90/60 mm Hg, Pulse rate 144/ min and respiratory rate of 30 min. What is the in itial fluid of choice for management :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 20 ml/Kg of0.9%Normalsaline Ref :Nelson 20th Ed/517,524 Explanation: The child has features of sepsis with early shock. In case of shock, aggressive fluid management in the form of normal saline bolus is recommended as per AHA/PALS guidelines. The bolus is 20 ml/kg, to be repeated 3-4 hrly if shock doesn’t improve. As per Nelson 20th Ed, “Rapid IV administration of 20 mL/kg isotonic fluid should be initiated in an attempt to reverse the shock state”. As per AAP guidelines, rapid isotonic bolus should be given within 5 minutes of presentation of a child in shock

choices.text: Arterial Oxygen Saturation Of Less than 75%

questions.text: Ina child with Tetralogy of fallot with fever and diarrhea, which of the following is the surest sign of cyanotic spell:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Absenceof murmur Ref: Nelson 20th Ed/2212; Park’s pediatric cardiology 6th Ed Explanation: Cyanotic spell (also known as tet spell) is a common complication of tetralogy of fallot in first year of life. It is characterized by worsening of cyanosis (with arterial SpO2 falling below 45-50%), hyperventilation and faint or absent pulmonary ejection systolic murmur. A child with a loud murmur initially, if presents with rapid breathing and cyanosis, absence of murmur is a useful clinical clue for cyanotic spell in that child. Remember: Hepatomegaly, basal crepitations and S3 gallop rhythm are signs of CCF in child

choices.text: Allergy Due To The Food Content

questions.text: A mother comes with her 3 months child asking the physician if she can give cereals to her child.What problem can this lead to in her child?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Allergy due to the food content Ref:Nelson 20th Ed/1139, IAP Pediatric Gastroenterology Review Explanation: Early administration of allergen food substances like fish, peanuts and wheat products before 4 months of age is hypothesized to increase the risk of sensitization and subsequent food allergy in the child. Also remember: Steps to prevent food allergy

choices.text: Reassure The parents and follow up after 6 months

questions.text: A 6 year old man child comes with complaint of bed wetting. the child is dry during the day and problem is only at night. Growth and development of the child was normal. Urine Microscopy Is normal and Urine Specific Gravity Is 1.020. How Will You manage:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Reassure the parents and follow up after 6 months Ref: NICE guidelines, AAP guidelines (updated) Explanation: If child is still having nocturnal enuresis at or beyond 6 years, he needs to be evaluated and if medical investigations are normal, referral to a psychiatrist is recommended for starting the child on behavior therapy, lifestyle modification, positive reinforcement and bed alarm trials. Points to remember: Bed alarm is more successful than drug therapy. Desmopressin is preferred over Imipramine Oral desmopressin is preferred over nasal desmopressin

questions.text: A Child Who Was Normal At Birth develops chronic liver failure and muscle weakness at 3 months of age.of investigation serumglucoseislowalong with ketoacidosis and decreased pH.ALT and AST are raised.Blood Lactate And Uric Acid Levels Are Normal.Intravenous Glucagon Given For meal raises the blood glucose level but does not raise glucose when given after an overnight fast. Liver Biopsy Shows Increased Glycogen in liver. Which Is The Enzyme likely to be defective in this child.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Debranching Enzyme Ref: Nelson Textbook Of Pediatrics 20/chapter76; CPDT Explanation: This child has type III glycogen storage disorder (Cori’s Disease) Features to remember for solving MCQs: Ketotic hypoglycaemia with liver involvement in the form of transaminitis Deficiency of debranching enzyme Absence of lactic acidosis and hyperuricemia (which are common in Von gerke disease) Liver biopsy shows increased glycogen IV glucagon within 2-3 hr of meals improves blood glucose, but that given after overnight fasting/beyond 6-8 hr of meal doesn’t improve blood glucose Dietary therapy is recommended

questions.text: Whichis the most common congenital abnormality in baby of diabetic women:
questions.solution: A. Ventricular Septal Defect Ref: Ghai Essential Pediatrics 8/ep181; Nelson 20th Ed/898, William’s Obstetrics Explanation: Most common congenital anomalies in infants of diabetic mothers (compiled from multiple sources) As a system, CVS >CNS As a group of anomalies, Neural tube defects are most common As a single disease, VSD is most common congenital anomaly Most specific anomaly is Caudal regression syndrome Most specific cardiac anomaly is TGA

questions.text: A 4year old childi s admitted in the ward with pneumonia and is on ventilation.He Develops Sudden progressive respiratory distress syndrome.The Following Chest x ray was recorded. What will you do Next:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Decrease Mechanical Ventilation Ref: Ghai Essential Pediatrics 8/ep393; Pediatric Critical Care by Fuhrman & Zimmermann Explanation: See the CXR. It is showing hyperinflation (8-9 I/C spaces are visible bilaterally). Development of hyperinflation in a child on ventilator suggests Iatrogenic hyperinflation as a complication due to high PEEP and can lead to pulmonary edema and progressive respiratory distress. Decreasing the ventilatory settings with focus on PaO2 and PaCO2 helps in improvement.

questions.text: A 5 year old male comes with complains of pain in neck and right shoulder with restricted range of motion. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Facioscapulohumeraldystrophy Ref: Nelson 20th Ed/2984; Forfar&Arneill Explanation: This patient has features of shoulder girdle muscle weakness along with winging of scapula (as shown in picture), which are suggestive of Facio-scapulo-humeral dystrophy.

choices.text: Bilateralinter costals chest tubes are present in correct place
Mediastinum is not shifted to right
Left sided pleural effusion is present

questions.text: A16 year male present with rapidly developing bilateral pleural effusion. The following chest radiograph was taken in the emergency.All are correct inter pretation about this radiograph except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pneumothorax is present Explanation: Pneumothorax appears as darkened shadow, with sharply defined border and often associated with shift of mediastinum to right. This CXR has no such presentation.

questions.text: Which of these medicines taken during pregnancy is responsible for the defect seen in the child below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Isotretinoin Ref: Nelson 19/e Chap 85 HUMAN TERATOGENS CAUSING CLEFT LIP ETHYL ALCOHOL DIPHENYL HYDANTOIN TRIMETHADIONE RETINOIDS METHOTREXATE HYPERTHERMIA SMOKING

questions.text: Palivizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody. For which of the following conditions has it been approved for?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Respiratory syncytial virus Ref: Nelson 20th Ed/2048 Explanation: Reduction in the severity and incidence of acute bronchiolitisbecause of RSV is possible through the administration of pooledhyperimmune RSV intravenous immunoglobulin and palivizumab, anintramuscular monoclonal antibody to the RSV F protein, before andduring RSV season. Palivizumab should be considered for infantsyounger than 2 yr of age with chronic lung disease, a history of prematurity,and some forms of congenital heart disease

choices.text: Refer to higher centre with mother giving frequent sips of ORS
Immediately admit the child, give IV fluids and then refer to higher center
Give first dose of antibiotic and refer to higher center
Send child home with few packets of ORS and call after 3 days.

questions.text: A 2-month-old child was brought to the subcenter by his mother with complaints of fever for two days. Weight of the child is 2kg. On examination, the child is restless and irritable, skin pinch went back in 2 seconds, oral mucosa is dry and eyes were sunken. There were ten pustules on his forehead. What should be done at the subcenter?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Give first dose of antibiotic and refer to higher center Ref: IMNCI guidelines, Ghai8/e, IAP Textbook of Pediatrics Explanation: This is a child with fever, 10 pustules, some dehydration. Any symptomatic febrile child with 10 or more pustules should be assumed to have systemic sepsis. This child needs first dose of antibiotic and started on ORS, followed by immediate referral to higher center for admission (We cannot admit in a subcenter). Among options given, C is the best possible answer (although not the ideal answer)

questions.text: A child presented at 2 years of age with delayed motor development, mental retardation and finger biting. He was normal at birth. He subsequently develops cerebral palsy arthritis and dies due to renal failure at age of 25 years. What is the likely enzyme deficiency implicated?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) HGPRT deficiency Ref: Nelson 20th Ed/746 Explanation: The child has cognitive delay, self-mutilation, CNS dysfunction and renal failure (probably due to hyperuricemia), which are suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. Lesch-Nyhan disease (LND) is a rare X-linked disorder of purine metabolism that results from HGPRT deficiency.

questions.text: A neonate on routine examination at birth was found to have hepatomegaly. Rest of the examination was essentially unremarkable. On investigations, Anti-CMV antibodies were found to be positive. What sequelae in later life is the child at risk of?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sensorineural hearing loss Ref: Nelson 20th Ed/1593 Explanation:The clinical findings of infants with symptomatic congenitalCMV infections can include hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes,jaundice, and in some cases microcephaly. Because hearing loss isthe most common long-term sequela associated with congenital CMV infection, the failure of an infant to pass a newborn hearing screeningexam should raise the possibility of congenital CMV infection.

questions.text: A neonate presented with cicatrizing skin lesions all over the body with hypoplasia of all limbs. An MRI of the brain revealed diffuse cerebral atrophy. An ophthalmologic evaluation reveals chorioretinitis. Which of these tests is most likely to show a positive result in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Anti-VZV antibody Ref: Nelson 20th Ed/1582 Explanation: The congenital varicella syndrome is characterized by cicatricial skin scarring in a zoster-like distribution; limb hypoplasia; and abnormalities of the neurologic system (e.g., microcephaly, cortical atrophy, seizures, and mental retardation), eye (e.g., chorioretinitis, microphthalmia, and cataracts), renal system (e.g., hydroureter and hydronephrosis), and autonomic nervous system (neurogenic bladder, swallowing dysfunction, and aspiration pneumonia). Low birthweight is common among infants with congenital varicella syndrome.

questions.text: What should be the ideal temperature in delivery room?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 25-28 degree C Ref: WHOThermal protection of Newborn guidelines Explanation: As per WHO guidelines on thermal management in neonates, the delivery room temperature recommended is 25-28 degrees Celsius (77.0-82.4 degrees Fahrenheit).

questions.text: In which of the diseases is the following appearance of calves seen in a child?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Muscular dystrophy Ref: Nelson 19/e Chap 600 Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) Most common genetic muscle wasting disease affecting children. Characterized by severe muscle weakness and wasting Disorder usually becomes apparent between 2 and 5 years of age. Patients are wheelchair bound by the age of 10. There is currently no cure and death occurs in mid-twenties due to respiratory insufficiency and/or heart failure

choices.text: Head circumference to abdominal circumference ratio
Mid-upper arm circumference to head circumference ratio
Weight in kilograms by cube of height in meters
Square root of height in feet by weight in grams

questions.text: Ponderal index is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Weight in kilograms by cube of height in meters Ref: Ghai 7/e pg 109; CPDT Explanation: PI is ratio of weight in kg divided by cube of height in meters. It is used to classify neonates into symmetrical and asymmetrical IUGR.

questions.text: Ideal route of drug delivery in neonatal resuscitation is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Through umbilical vein Ref: NALS 2015 guidelines Explanation: Umbilical venous route is the fastest route to administer drugs in neonatal resuscitation, followed by intraosseous route. Peripheral venous route takes longer time due to difficulty in access and stability of access in neonates in first few hours of life.

choices.text: Observe only as it is mostly physiological jaundice
Liver function tests and liver biopsy as it is mostly due to cholestasis

questions.text: A neonate presented with jaundice on first day of life.How will you manage?
questions.solution: C. Phototherapy Ref: AIIMS WHO Neonatal protocols 2014 Explanation: Presence of jaundice in first 24 hr is suggestive of pathological/serious jaundice and needs to be started on phototherapy till investigations are done. As per AIIMS protocol, any baby with serious jaundice, first start phototherapy, then send Total serum bilirubin and decide next course of action.

choices.text: Inj. Betamethasone 12 mg for 2 doses 12 hours apart
Inj. Betamethasone 12 mg for 2 deses 24 hours apart
Inj. Dexamethasone 6 mg for 4 doses 12 hours apart
Inj. Dexamethasone12 mg for 2 doses 12 hours apart

questions.text: What is the recommended dose of steroids for attaining fetal lung maturity?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Inj. Dexamethasone 6 mg for 4 doses 12 hours apart Ref: WHO Update 2016-17 on antenatal pregnancy outcomes Explanation: As per recent guidelines, Dexamethasone in a dose of 6 mg i.m. for 4 doses is preferred over Betamethasone for fetal lung maturity in preterm labour.

choices.text: IV Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to higher centre
Give oral fluids and ask the mother to continue the same and visit again next day
Consider severe dehydration start IV fluids, IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
No need any treatment. Just observe

questions.text: A 5-years-old kid brought to the hospital with history of loose stools. No history of fever or blood in stools. Mother says he is irritable and drinks water if given. On examination eyes sunken and Skin pinch test- the skin retracted within two seconds but not immediately. What is the treatment the kid?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

choices.text: Give IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
Oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs and send home
No need of treatment only home remedies

questions.text: 18 months old kid brought to the hospital with history of breathlessness, fever, cough and cold. On examination respiratory rate was 46/min, there were no chest retractions. Which is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs and send home Ref. Revised WHO classification and treatment of childhood pneumonia at health facilities 2015 Explanation: As per revised WHO ARI control program (2015), This child will be categorised as ‘Pneumonia’ Management of ‘Pneumonia’ category would be ‘Oral amoxicillin and home care advice’

choices.text: Diagnosed only by persistent presence of IgM antibody after 6 months
It’s the most common cause of non-syndromic sensory neural hearing loss
Mothers of developing countries who transmit the virus are usually symptomatic

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding congenital CMV infection?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) It’s the most common cause of non-syndromic sensory neural hearing loss Ref. Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th edition, Page 1592 Explanation: MATERNAL CMV INFECTION Primary CMV infection occurs in 1% to 3% of pregnant women. It is estimated that 30% to 40% of foetuses of women with primary infection will become infected with CMV, and approximately 15% of these foetuses will develop significant disease. Infection during early gestation likely carries a higher risk of severe fetal disease. Maternal CMV tends to be asymptomatic and patients will rarely be diagnosed by clinical symptoms alone. CONGENITAL CMV INFECTION Among congenital infection 10% cases are symptomatic 90% cases are asymptomatic Severe multi organ disease is infrequent and occurs in less than 5% of infants with congenital CMV infections. Classical manifestations Hepatosplenomegaly Petechial rashes Jaundice Microcephaly Intracranial calcification Neutropenia Laboratory Findings Direct hyperbilirubinemia, elevation of hepatic transaminases, CBC findings: Reduced platelets, anemia, Abnormal findings on cranial USG. CSF Analysis Elevation of mono-nuclear cells and protein levels in CSF Chorioretinitis is seen in some of the affected infants (<10%) Hearing loss is the most common long-term sequel of congenital CMW infection Diagnosis The diagnosis is made if CMV is identified in urine, saliva, blood, or respiratory secretions and defined as congenital infection if found within the first 2 weeks of life and as perinatal infection if after 4 weeks of life Spin-enhanced culture or “shell vial.” CMV antigen. CMV polymerase chain reaction (PCR). CMV IgG and IgM. Universal newborn hearing screening is recommended to detect hearing loss as early as possible. HEARING LOSS Genetic Approximately 50% of congenital hearing loss is thought to be of genetic origin, 70% recessive, 15% autosomal dominant and 15% with other types of genetic transmission Most common genetic cause of hearing loss is a mutation in the connexion 26(Cx26) gene, located on chromosome 13q11-12 Approximately 30% of infants with hearing loss have other associated medical problems that are part of a syndrome (Alport, Pierre Robin, Usher, Waardenburg Syndrome, Trisomy 21) Nongenetic CMV is the most common cause of nonhereditary sensorineural hearing loss Persistence of IGg after six month is diagnostic. All babies born are not always symptomatic.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in fetal alcohol syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Macrocephaly Ref. Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th edition, Page 895 Explanation: Fetal alcohol syndrome is associated with microcephaly, not macrocephaly FETAL ALCOHOL SYNDROME High levels of alcohol ingestion during pregnancy can be damaging to embryonic and fetal development. A specific pattern of malformation identified as fetal alcohol syndrome has been documented, and major and minor components of the syndrome are expressed in 1-2 infants/1,000 live births Characteristics of fetal alcohol syndrome • Prenatalonset and persistence of growth deficiency for length, weight, and head circumference – Microcephly, short stature, Failure to thrive • Facial abnormalities, including short palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds, maxillary hypoplasia, micrognathia, smooth philtrum, and a thin, smooth upper lip • Cardiac defects – VSD and ASD • Minor joint and limb abnormalities, including some restriction of movement, altered palmar crease patterns and Hypoplastic fifth finger nails • Delay of development and mental deficiency varying from borderline to severe – Holoprosencephaly • Treatment of infants with fetal alcohol syndrome is difficult because no specific therapy exists. • These infants may remain hypotonic and tremulous despite sedation, and the prognosis is poor. • Counselling with regard to recurrence is important. • Prevention is achieved by eliminatingalcohol intake after conception. Image Based Questions Section To make the fastest diagnosis in time bound MCQs, look for a short palpebral fissures; long, smooth philtrum with vermillion border; and hirsutism in the newborn Extra Edge on FAS and Related Congenital Anomalies • Severity of maternal alcohol use and extent and severity of pattern is most predictive of ultimate prognosis in FAS. • Growth deficiency, borderline to mild mental retardation, dysmorphic facial features, short neck, abnormal palmar crease, Rib abnormalities, Hirsutism, Cupid’s-bow lips suggest®Fetal Hydantoin Syndrome [Prenatal exposure to Phenytoin] • Cleft lip, Cardiac defects, Long, thin fingers and toes; Convex nails, meningomyelocele suggests a fetal Valproate Syndrome.

questions.text: A 14-years-old infant had conjunctivitis, which later developed into respiratory distress and pneumonia. Chest X-ray showed bilateral lung infiltrates. Peripheral smear count showed 14,300/dl (N 43, L 54, E3). Which of the following is the most likely organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Chlamydia trachomatis Ref. Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th edition, Page 1495, 3037 Explanation: Organism causing conjunctivitis and pneumonia in neonatal period is Chlamydia trachomatis.Another organism which can involve conjunctiva and lung during neonatal period is Staph aureus. Remember that staphylococcal pneumonia shows leucopenia and is aggressive. NEONATAL CHLAMYDIA TRACHOMATIS INFECTION Conjunctivitis Mothers with active untreated conjunctivitis transmits to approximately 30-50% of infants born Onset of symptoms – 5-14 days after delivery. In case of prolonged rupture of membranes the symptoms start earlier. Clinical Symptoms Mild conjunctival injection, mucoid to purulent discharge, chemosis, and rarely pseudomembrane formation Bleeds on taking a swab Pneumonia – seen in 10-20% of infants Onset 1-3 months of age; may occur as early as 10-15 days of life Persistent cough, tachypnea and absence of fever Auscultation – rales and wheeze The absence of fever and wheezing helps to distinguish C. trachomatis pneumonia from respiratory syncytial virus pneumonia ® a very important clinical differential diagnosis in older children Lab Findings Peripheral eosinophilia (<400 cells/ uL.) Chest X-ray – Hyperinflation accompanied by minimal interstitial or alveolar infiltrates. Treatment Erythromycin (50 mg/kg/day divided 4 times a day PO for 14 days) Azithromycin suspension (20 mg/kg/day once daily PO for 3 days).

questions.text: Dried blood spot test in neonates is used for:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Dried blood spot testing (DBS) is a form of biosampling where blood samples are blotted and dried on filter paper. The dried samples can easily be shipped to an analytical laboratory and analysed using various methods such as DNA amplification or HPLC.

questions.text: A 4-days-old neonate is brought by the mother to the paediatrician and is found to have a bilirubin of 18 g/dl. What is the next step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Promoting breastfeeding for infants with jaundice, assessing for the adequacy of breastfeeding, and increasing the frequency to eight to 12 times per day.5 Supplementation with formula may be considered if the infant's intake is inadequate, weight loss is excessive, the infant appears dehydrated, or the jaundice is severe. Phototherapy should be interrupted for breastfeeding unless the infant's bilirubin levels are approaching those that require exchange transfusion.

questions.text: Patient with growth retardation, delayed milestones with kinky hair. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Menkes syndrome is a disorder that affects copper levels in the body. It is characterized by sparse, kinky hair; failure to gain weight and grow at the expected rate (failure to thrive); and deterioration of the nervous system. Additional signs and symptoms include weak muscle tone (hypotonia), sagging facial features, seizures, developmental delay, and intellectual disability. Children with Menkes syndrome typically begin to develop symptoms during infancy and often do not live past age 3. Early treatment with copper may improve the prognosis in some affected individuals. In rare cases, symptoms begin later in childhood. Occipital horn syndrome (sometimes called X-linked cutis laxa) is a less severe form of Menkes syndrome that begins in early to middle childhood. It is characterized by wedge-shaped calcium deposits in a bone at the base of the skull (the occipital bone), coarse hair, and loose skin and joints.

questions.text: The milestones of a three year old child are considered delayed if he is unable to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Motor milestones of 3 year old are Walk up and down stairs, alternating feet -- one foot per step Kick, throw, and catch a ball • Climb well Run more confidently and ride a tricycle Hop and stand on one foot for up to five seconds Walk forward and backward easily Bend over without falling Help put on and remove clothing Use spoon effectively

questions.text: A child presented at 18 months of age who has never been vaccinated before. Which vaccines will you administer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency with a history of ingestion of button battery, on X-ray it was found in the stomach or duodenum. What is the next step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Absence of which of the following milestone in 3 years old child is called delayed development?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) At 3 years • Walk up and down stairs, alternating feet -- one foot per step • Kick, throw, and catch a ball • Climb well • Run more confidently and ride a tricycle • Hop and stand on one foot for up to five seconds • Walk forward and backward easily • Bend over without falling • Help put on and remove clothing • Use spoon effectively

questions.text: After the delivery of an infant of diabetic mother, blood glucose of the infant was 60 mg/dl. Which other investigation does the sister expects that the physician would ask her to do?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Infants of diabetic mother have hyperinsulinism, hence they are prone to hypog;lycemia. They also suffer from hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia. So look for serum calcium levels.

choices.text: OPV 3 doses, 1 IPV, 3 Pentavalent and 1 measles
BCG, OPV 3 doses, 3 IPV, 3 Pentavalent and 1 measles
OPV 3 doses, 1 IPV, 3 Pentavalent and 2 measles

questions.text: An un-immunized 13 months old child comes to you in OPD, according to the latest immunizations schedule, what vaccines will you advise?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Correct order of suctioning during neonatal resuscitation is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Firstly the mouth should be suctioned as it is a big cavity. Later the nose is suctioned and then baby starts breathing. Indications of bag and mask ventilation with 100% O2 are Apnoes/ gasping HR<100 / min after 30 sec of PPV Central cyanosis

questions.text: How long should a child be isolated after being diagnosed with bacterial meningitis to prevent further transmission?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In patients especially with Neisseria and H,influenzae meningitis, isolate them for 24 hrs after starting antibiotic therapy. Hospital staff must wear a mask when they are within 3 m of the patient. Chemoprophylaxis for contacts include: ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin or fluroquinolones.

questions.text: You have been called to declare a brain dead 12-years-old child in PICU, all of the given are signs of brain death except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Brain death is a clinical diagnosis where there is irreversible loss of all brain functions, including the brainstem. It is important to recognize signs that are consistent with brain death and differentiate them from conditions that might appear similar but are not indicative of brain death. Here’s why A. Normal BP without pharmacological support is incorrect as a sign of brain death: • In brain death, autonomic functions such as blood pressure regulation are no longer functioning because the brainstem is non-functional. Therefore, a patient who is brain dead usually has unstable blood pressure, often requiring pharmacological support to maintain it. • Normal blood pressure without pharmacological support would not be consistent with brain death, as brainstem failure typically leads to instability in blood pressure. Why the other options are signs of brain death: B. Positive spinal reflexes on stimulation: Even though the brain is dead, spinal reflexes (like the spinal cord's response to stimulation) can still be present. These reflexes are mediated by the spinal cord, which can function independently of the brain after brain death. C. Sweating and tachycardia: Sweating and tachycardia can occur due to the loss of brainstem regulation, leading to autonomic dysfunction. These signs can still be seen in brain-dead patients. D. Decorticate and decerebrate posturing: These types of posturing are reflex movements that occur when the brain is still functioning at some level, especially the brainstem. However, decerebrate posturing can still occur in a brain-dead patient because reflex movements mediated by the spinal cord may be observed.

questions.text: Craniopagus is defined as fusion of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: An adolescent school girl complaints of dropping objects from hands, it get precipitated during morning and during exams. There is no history of loss of consciousness and her cousin sister has been diagnosed with epilepsy. EEG was done and was suggestive of epileptic spikes. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: A Child wit thalassemia treated for cardiac arrythmia before due to iron overload. Child came for regular transfusion now. During transfusion complained of back pain and sweating. Next step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Back pain during transfusion is an omnious sign of acute hemolytic transfusion reactions. Next step will be to stop the transfusion . Suspected transfusion reactions include fever ± chills and back pain. Tests to be done after the reaction are CBC, Coombs test, urine routine to look for hemolysis

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The image shown is an Esophageal temperature probe. Used to monitor temperature intraoperatively by keeping the probe in oropharyngeal\nasopharyngeal or rectal area.

questions.text: BCG vaccine though not protective provides effective protection for?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) BCG vaccine doesn’t give protection against pulmonary tuberculosis infection. But is gives protection against severe disseminated forms of TB like tubercular meningitis and military tuberculosis.

questions.text: A baby in ICU, has seizure movement on upper limb bilateral as shown below (for videos download e-medicoz app). Which is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Which of the following is primarily secreted fetal adrenal cortex
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Placents lacks 17 OH and cannot synthesiseestrogen . it uses featal DHEAS to synthesise estrogen Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate, abbreviated as DHEA sulfate or DHEA-S, also known as androstenolone sulfate, is an endogenous androstane steroid that is produced by the adrenal cortex. It is the 3β-sulfate ester and a metabolite of dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) that circulates in far greater relative concentrations. The steroid is hormonally inert and is instead an important neurosteroid and neurotrophin.

questions.text: Newly introduced in universal immunization program in India?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) MR vaccine was introduced on 5thfeb 2017 in 5 states : Karnataka, Goa, Lakshadweep, tamilnadu and puducherry

questions.text: In children with classical galactosemia all are true except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Galactosemia occurs due to deficiency of enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GPUT) and there is accumulation of galactose-1- phosphate. galactose-1- phosphate is hepatotoxic. These children suffer from e-coli sepsis, oil droplet cataract. Majority of children recover with dietary management by consuming lacoste-free diet or galactose-free diet.

questions.text: A 10-years-old girl present with polyuria and polydipsia with hypokalemia, hypercalciuria and metabolic alkalosis. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Barters syndrome It is an inherited defect in N+ - 2Cl – K+ channel on thick ascending loop of henle. There is defective absorption of Na+,K+ and Ca+ ions leading to hypokalemia and hypercalciuria.

choices.text: Measure to the nearest of 1 cm
Tanner’s chart contains the normal values
Indirectly indicates the caloric reserve of the body

questions.text: Which of the following is not true in assessing skin fold thickness?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Skin fold thickness measurement is done inorder to asses caloric reserve of the body. It is done over the triceps. It is measured to the nearest millimetre (not cm).

choices.text: Skinfold thickness is measured in sub scapular region
Weight is measured to the nearest 100 gram
Standing height is about 1.7 cm less than recumbent length

questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Skin fold thickness measurement is done inorder to asses caloric reserve of the body. It is done over the triceps. It is measured to the nearest millimetre (not cm). DIfference of standing height and recumbent length is 0.8 cm

choices.text: Infants of congenital rubella syndrome can shed virus in respiratory secretions upto 1 year of age
Risk of developing diabetes mellitus is considerably higher in congenital rubella syndrome
Cataract in CRS is always bilateral
Risk of congenital defects is high when fetus is infected during the first trimester

questions.text: True regarding congenital rubella (CRS) syndrome are all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Congenital rubella syndrome a. Manifests as cataract, sensorineural deafness and cardiac defects. The infants affected may continue to shed the virus upto 1 yr in their pharynx, it is rare after 2 yrs of age. Late complications of this syndrome may include endocrine abnormalities like thyroid disorders, diabetes mellitus, growth hormone deficiency etc. catact can be unilateral or bilateral. Risk of congenital defects is high when fetus is infected during the first trimester

questions.text: A child with pigment dilution of skin and eyes, hemorrhagic diathesis, ceroid depositions within the reticuloendothelial system has:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • HermanskyPudlak syndrome It is an autosomal recessive syndrome. Patient may present with occulo-cutaneous albinism with bleding diatheses, pulmonary fibrosis and granulomatous colitis. • Bloom syndrome Autosomal recessive chromosomal instability disorder characeterised by immunodeficiencies and short stature • Alezzandrini syndrome It’s a rare syndrome in which patient has vitiligo which is unilateral and facial. They have unilateral retinal degeneration and poliosis.

questions.text: A 14-years-old boy was brought in a collapsed state with history of 2 episodes of vomiting and had feeble pulse and cold, clammy limbs. ECG is given (Figure). What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sine wave pattern seen on ECG. Next step in managemnetis to do CPR and give IV calcium gluconate.

questions.text: Symptoms suggestive of Scarlet fever are all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • Nagayama spots are seen in exanthema subitum • Scarlet fever typically presents with Sand paper rash accompanied by circum oral rash and strawberry toungue. Later the rashes desquamate with sparing of palms and soles

choices.text: Koplik’s spots cannot be seen in conjunctival or vaginal mucosa
Vitamin A administration is part of management of clinical measles
CD150 and PVRL4 are receptors for measles virus
Pneumonia is the common cause of death in children with measles

questions.text: Which statement regarding Measles is false?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Koplik spots are pathognomic lesions of measeals which appear 1 to 3 days before the onset of disease. The appear on inner aspect of cheeks at the level of premolars. They may be on lips, hard palate, gingiva and rarely seen on conjunctiva and vaginal mucosa also. Measles act via CD150 which are lymphocyte activating molecules and it attaches itself to PVRL4 are receptor which are expressed on trachea, oral mucosa and lungs. Pneumonia is the common cause of death in children with measles. Vitamin a is known to prevent complications of measles

choices.text: Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 gene, DNA polymerase
CMV is not detected in the breast milk of mother with CMV infection
Ganciclovir is indicated in CMV infection in Immunocompetent children
Ganciclovir resistant CMV strains do not show cross resistance to Foscarnet.

questions.text: True regarding CMV in children:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CMV resistance is diagnosed by detecting specific genetic mutations. UL97 mutations confer resistance to ganciclovir and valganciclovir, and a UL54 mutation confers multidrug resistance. Risk factors for resistance include prolonged or previous anti-CMV drug exposure or inadequate dosing, absorption, or bioavailability. Host risk factors include type of HCT and degree of immunosuppression.

questions.text: A forceps delivered premature baby develops fever, abnormal behaviour, bulging fontanelle 5 days after birth. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Which of the following features of rheumatic fever is not due to molecular mimicry?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Antigens against Streptococcal antigens may cross react with various proteins of myocardium such as meromyosin, myosin and valve related proteins.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in prune belly syndrome
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Prune belly syndrome • Classical traid of this syndrome includes : cryptorchidism, uretero-hydronephros and deficient anterior abdominal wall.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criteria of SAM
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Criteria for SAM A) W/H <-3SD B) MAC < 11.5cm C) B/L pedal edema

choices.text: Bilateral tumors are more common in syndromes

questions.text: A 5yr old presents with renal mass. Considering the most common cause in this age group which of the following statements is not true.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) • Wilms tumour is the most common renal malignancy in children. Seen in <15 yr old. Mostly unilateral, but may be bilateral in syndromic associations like : WAGR, Denysdrash syndrome, beckwith Weidman syndrome. • WAGR increases the risk upto 50% • Triphasic histology: cells are of three types :blstemal, stromal and epithelial type of cells.

questions.text: Administration of PGE1 analogue will deteriorate condition in which of the following EXCEPT:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Left atrial obstruction or pulmonary venous obstruction is worsened by PGE1

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common craniosynostosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Scaphocephaly is premature closure of sagittal suture accounts to 50% of craniosynostosis.

questions.text: While resuscitation of a child with head injury giving mannitol and 3% NS together, how much should be the osmolality
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Hyperosmolar therapy is used in head injury . we can use either 3% NS or mannitol Mannitol 0.5 to 1 gm/kg in children as iv infusion Hypertonic saline (3% NS) : Bolus of 5ml/kg followed by continuous infusion.

questions.text: 10 year old child presented with cyanosis and on examination was found to have a loud murmur at lower left sternal border. Xray as shown is shown below. Most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Figure of 8 or snowman appearance occurs on supracardiac TAPVC. The most common TAPVC is supracardiac variety in which the pulmonary veins join superior venacava.

choices.text: Children >12 months with no vaccination with h influenza

questions.text: Lumbar puncture in a case of meningitis is indicated in all of the below except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) LP is contraindicated in patients with suspicion for intracranial mass, or other indication pointing to increased intracranial pressure; hemodynamic instability like respiratory compromise; status epilepticus; any underlying spinal cord anatomic abnormalities, coagulopathy, or spinal or epidural abscess; or if there is an infection of the superimposing lumbar site such as cellulitis or skin or subcutaneous abscess.

questions.text: Which among the following is/are seen as an effect of hypoxic -ischemic injury in a neonate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B & E) Ref: Nelson 20th Ed Explanation: In perinatal asphyxia/hypoxic-ischemic injury Umbilical artery blood pH is commonly below 7.0 Cerebral injury manifests as infarcts, HIE, tone abnormalities and seizure Asphyxial lung injury may manifest as RDS-like features, pulmonary hypertension and O2 requirement Subcutaneous fat necrosis and DIC may occur Adrenal haemorrhage can develop CVS may show ischemia, hypotension and regurgitation from tricuspid and mitral valves GIT perforation and NEC may develop Hypoglycemia and hypocalcemia are common in the first few hours of life

questions.text: Feature(s) of Crouzon syndrome may include?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A,C,D) Ref: Nelson 20th Ed, Forfar and Arneill Explanation: Crouzon syndrome • It is a genetic disorder due to mutation in FGFR-2 gene, characterized by the premature fusion of certain skull bones (craniosynostosis). • Signs and symptoms of Crouzon syndrome may include wide-set, bulging eyes; strabismus (misalignment of the eyes); a small, "beak-shaped" nose; and an underdeveloped upper jaw, with maxillary hypoplasia • Other features may include dental problems, hearing loss, and/or cleft lip and palate. The severity of signs and symptoms can vary among affected people, even within a family. • Intelligence is usually normal, but intellectual disability may be present • Digit abnormalities are absent

choices.text: Mouth of baby is wide open
Upper areola is more visible than lower

questions.text: Which among the following is/are good signs of attachment to the breast during breastfeeding by a baby?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B,C,D) Explanation: Signs of effective attachment during breastfeeding • Chin firmly touches the breast • Mouth of baby is wide open • Lower lip of baby is curled outwards, ie everted • Upper areola more visible than lower • No pain on feeding • Cheeks stay rounded during feeding • Rhythmically sucks and swallows

questions.text: All among the following is/are metabolic causes of pediatric liver disease except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ref: OP Ghai 8th Ed, Nelson 20th Ed Explanation: Metabolic liver diseases in children • Conditions with hepatocellular necrosis: Wilson disease, hemochromatosis, galactosemia, tyrosinemia, alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, reye’s syndrome • Conditions with cholestasis: Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, Cystic fibrosis, Niemann-Pick disease, Byler’s disease • Conditions with abnormal storage: Gaucher disease, Glycogen storage disorders etc. Histiocytosis X, also known as Langerhans Cell histiocytosis is a monoclonal lymphoproliferative disorder, not a metabolic liver disease.

questions.text: Breast milk contains sufficient amounts of?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A,B,D) Ref: WHO breastfeeding guide Explanation: Remember that although protein in breast milk is less than animal milk, it is sufficient enough for the baby. Breast milk has high lactose, good micronutrients, including iron and Vitamin C. The three substances deficient in breast milk are Vitamin K, D and B1

choices.text: Intravascular hemolysis secondary to fava beans in G6PD deficiency

questions.text: Cause(s) of congenital unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia may include?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A,B,D) Ref: Nelson 20th Ed Explanation: Sepsis, Crigglernajar syndrome and Gilbert syndrome can all present with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in neonates and even in first 24 hr of life (the so-called congenital jaundice). Rotor syndrome produces conjugated jaundice hence not the answer. Hemolysis in response to oxidant stress (e.g. fava beans) in G6PD deficiency will not present in first 24 hr and hence will not be the answer.

questions.text: Craniosynostosis is associated with?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, B, E) Craniosynostosis is premature fusion of skull sutures. Syndromes associated with craniosynostosis are • Apert syndrome: sporadic or autosomal dominant with FGFR mutation. Features include Craniosynostosis, anti mongoloid slnt of eyes, syndactyly, cleft palate • Crouzon syndrome: autosomal dominant syndrome with FGRF2 / FGFR3 mutation. Features include craniosynostosis, beaked nose, no cleft palate and no syndactyly • Carpenter syndrome • Pfeiffer syndrome

choices.text: Downward slant of eyes medial to lateral

questions.text: Clinical feature(s) of down syndrome child may include?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, C) • Fissured tongue may be present in 1 to 2 % of downs syndrome patients. • They have short non webbed neck. • Ears are small dysplastic and low set. • Mongoloid slant of eyes are present in which there is downward slant of eyes lateral to medial. Numerous randomized trials have demonstrated that continuing antipsychotic therapy lowers the chance of recurrence for up to two years. Most books mention treatment duration for schizophrenia as: 1st episode: 1-2 years 2nd episode: 2-5 years 3rd/Recurrent: Lifetime

questions.text: Surgeries done in a child with tetralogy of fallot (TOF) may include?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A & B)

choices.text: Wide carrying angle at the elbow
Less risk of congenital heart disease

questions.text: True regarding Noonan syndrome is/are?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, B, C, D) Noonan syndrome • Incidence is 1 in 1000 ro 1 in 2500 live births • 80% cases are sporadic and 20% are autosomal dominant • All mutations involve RAS – MAP kinase pathway abnormality. Most common mutation involves PTPN- 11 gene present of chromosome 12q 24.1 chromosome. It is a miss-sense mutation. Other mutations include: KRAS, SHP-2, BRAF, CBL, SOS-1 • Clinical features resemble turners syndrome. Additional features are: male> female, anti mongoloid slant of eyes, wide philtrum, low IQ, congenital heart diseases like pulmonary stenosis.

choices.text: Present more commonly in premature babies

questions.text: True about lanugo hair is/are?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B, C) Lanugo hais are thin non pigmented hairs present in newboens all ver the body except palms and soles

choices.text: Diagnosed commonly in the neonatal period
Chemotherapy is not useful at any stage

questions.text: True regarding Wilms tumour is/are?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B,C) • Wilms tumour is commonly diagnosed at the age of 2 to 6 years • Aniridia is a part of WAGR syndrome. WAGR includes: wilms tumour, aniridia, genitourinary abnormality and retardation of growth • Mutation is in WT1 gene or PAX – 6 gene • Pseudocapsule made up of fibrous tissue is present on the tumour which fails to prevent metastasis of tumour cells. • Wilms tumour is a large tumour which may be unipolar or bipolar. • Chemotheraphy is treatment of choice for stage 3 and 4. Agents used are actinomycin d, doxorubicin and vinca alkaloids

choices.text: Hepatitis B immunoglobulin at birth and vaccine at 3 months
Hepatitis B immunoglobulin and vaccine both immediately at birth
Hepatitis B immunoglobulin and vaccine both at 3 months
Hepatitis B vaccine at birth and immunoglobulin at 3 months
Hepatitis B immunoglobulin at birth and vaccine at 6 months

questions.text: A child is born to a mother who is hepatitis B positive. What is the management to do for the baby?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Child born to hepatitis B positive mother has two possibilities • Mother is HbSAg negative and has low viral load: child should be given 1st dose of hepB vaccine at birth, 2nd dose given in 1 to 3 months and second dose given at 6 to 18 months. Immunoglobulin need not be administered to the baby. • Mother is HbsAg positive: hepB immunoglobulin ( HBIG) given within 12 hrs of birth along with first dose of HepB vaccine. , 2nd dose given in 1 to 3 months and second dose given at 6 to 18 months. Post vaccination testing should be done in 9 to 18 months, we check for HbSAg and Anti- HbSAg.

choices.text: Also known as Menkes Kinky hair syndrome
Copper and ceruloplasmin levels are elevated
Copper and histidine are useful in the management

questions.text: All are true about a child with Hypopigmented hair & mutation involving ATP7A gene ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, C & E) Menkes kinky hair syndrome: also known as trichopoliodystrophy • Copper levels are decreased • Trichorrhexis nodosa is fracturing of fine hair. • Copper and histidine administration is done parenterally and ideally started within 1st 2 months of life

questions.text: Which of the following fontanelle is last to fuse
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Anterior fontanelle closes at 18 to 24 months of age • Posterior fontanelle is the first to close

choices.text: 30 ml ORS half hourly for two hours
350 ml IV normal saline in half hour

questions.text: A 6 kg child came with sunken eye, skin pinched going back I less than 2 seconds, irritable and drinking eagerly. What next step for management-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) The above clinical scenario falls under some dehydration / moderate dehydration. It requires 75ml/kg ORS over next 4 hrs. The correct answer is 300 ml of ORS over next 4 hrs. For severe dehydration we give ringer lactate 100ml/kg over 3hrs in older children and over 6 hrs in infants

choices.text: It occurs in first seven days of life
It shows severe pulmonary infiltrate with pulmonary edema
CPAP is required in its management

questions.text: All of the following is true about ARDS except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Acute respiratory distress syndrome can occur in any stage of life. (RDS occurs in new born)

choices.text: PPV with oxygen at room concentration
PPV with 100% oxygen and chest compression
PPV with 100% oxygen and chest compression with epinephrine

questions.text: A new born with heart rate is less than 60 beats per minute came to paediatrician. What will be the first step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Heart rate <60 is an indication to give chest compressions and positive pressure ventilation with 100% oxygen. Other indications for PPV with 100% oxygen are a. Apnea/ gasping after initial steps b. HR <100/min after 30 sec of PPV c. Central cyanosis despite 100% oxygen

choices.text: Abnormal dendritic morphology in cortical pyramidal cells

questions.text: All of the following are characteristic of Rett syndrome except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Rett syndrome is one of the pervasive developmental disorder caused due to Mecp2 gene mutation. It is X linked dominant, lethal in male fetuses. This is seen in females and presents with reduced brain growth after 6 to 18 months of life. This causes microcephaly. Other features are: hand wringing movements and repetitive movements. They have abnormal dendritic morphology of cortical pyramidal cells.

questions.text: Olympian Brow and Rhagades are seen in-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Features of early congenital syphilis are a. Mucocutaneous rash/ rhinitis ( snuffles) b. Lymphadenopathy c. Haematological like auto immune anemia d. Renal lesions e. Skeletal ( osteochondritis and metaphysistis) f. Glaucoma g. Pseudoparalysis of parrot Features of late congenital syphilis are a. Hutchinson teeth, mulberry molars b. Saddle nose, frontal bossing, olympian’s brow, higoumenaki sign ( sternoclavicle) c. Rhagades ( cracks over angle of mouth) d. Interstitial keratitis e. Nerve deafness

questions.text: Children with germline retinoblastoma are more likely to develop other primary malignancies in their later lifetime course. Which of the following malignancy can occur in such patients:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Osteosarcoma of lower limbs When there is a mutation or loss of function in the Rb gene, it increases the risk of developing retinoblastoma, a malignant tumor of the retina. ( RB gene is a tumor Suppressor gene) -There is a strong association between hereditary retinoblastoma and Rb gene mutations with an increased risk of osteosarcoma, particularly in the teenage and young adult years

questions.text: Boot shaped heart in TOF is due to?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) TOF consists of • Large unrestrictive VSD • Pulmonary stenosis • Over-riding or aorta • Right ventricle hypertrophy Boot shaped heart is produced due two reasons a. Concavity produced due to right ventricle outflow obstruction ie decreased pulmonary outflow b. Broadening and upturning of apex due to right ventricle hypertrophy

questions.text: Bidexterous grasp is seen at what age?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • Single best answer 5 months. (ref: Nelson, illingworth)

questions.text: Which vaccine is supposed to be given every year
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Not a part of national immunization schedule. Followed by IAP schedule • Recommended at age group 6 months to 5 years • Given annually before onset of influwnza season • Two types: trivalent, quadrivalent

questions.text: APGAR score of 3 at one minute indicates
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Where to look for pre-ductal O2 saturation in PDA in a 3 minute born infant
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Probe to check SpO2 is always put on neonatal right hand . this is because ductus arteriosus is still open, any reading distal to ductus arteriosus may be inaccurate.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Seen in between skin foldings.

Gain of function mutation is always seen

questions.text: True about fragile X syndrome is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Repeat seen in fragile X syndrome is CGG

questions.text: MRP 2 is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Dubin Johnson syndrome • Autosomal recessive • Absent of multiple drug resistant protein -2 ( MRP-2) : found of canalicular membrane • Total urinary coproporphyrin is normal. But type I > type III. • In normal humans type III is more than type I
